awd_titl_txt: IDBR: Type A: Development of a yeast-based continuous culture system for detecting bioavailable phosphate
awd_abstract_narration:
An award is made to The University of Notre Dame to develop a remotely deployable yeast based biosensor that measures the amount of bioavailable phosphate in water.  Eutrophication, pollution of surface water supplies through excess nutrients, can result in harmful algal blooms and the degradation of the quality of surface waters throughout the globe.  Thus, the Broader Impacts of the project include helping to reduce the over abundance of nutrients in water supplies, protecting the environment, drinking water, and property values, and optimizing fertilizer use (reducing farming costs and conserving the limited resource phosphate). The education and outreach efforts will include development of a simplified batch-culture-based assay for use in schools and community settings, which will broaden environmental participation and awareness of the need to reduce phosphate waste. In addition, the analytical chemistry and ecology students involved in the project will each receive cross-disciplinary training in the other field.

Improving the technology for measuring phosphate is important because eutrophication (pollution through excess nutrients) is degrading the quality of surface waters throughout the globe, and monitoring of phosphate is largely still limited to laborious lab-based, wet chemistry approaches. The goal of the project is to address this problem by developing a biologically-based phosphate sensor that is continuous, relatively inexpensive, remotely deployable, able to test turbid water, and based on monitoring the growth of the yeast Saccharomyces cerevisiae. The principle behind the device is that all organisms (including yeast) need phosphate to grow; yeast are ideal organisms for this work for reasons including their robustness to environmental perturbation and resistance to water-borne viruses. Since yeast growth is linear with phosphate concentration in the relevant phosphate concentration range, changes in the amount of bioavailable phosphate in water will be measured by monitoring the growth and respiration of yeast in this continuous culture system under conditions where the test water is the only source of phosphate. Because this sensor will measure bioavailable phosphate, not simply dissolved reactive phosphate (DRP) or total phosphorous (TP) as measured by other standard approaches, it will represent an important new tool for any environmental or engineering studies involving freshwater and should provide insight into previously inaccessible aspects of nutrient dynamics in aquatic systems.

por.por_cntn:
Eutrophication (water pollution through accumulation of excess nutrients) is a problem that reduces water quality, wastes limited resources, and has negative economic impacts to groups including fishermen, landowners, and cities. To combat eutrophication, it is necessary to identify the sources of excess nutrients, enabling farmers to reduce fertilizer inputs, save money, and preserve nonrenewable resources.

In the Great Lakes region, the primary nutrient responsible for eutrophication is phosphorus (P). Existing methods for P detection and measurement often produce hazardous waste, require skilled technicians working in an analytical laboratory setting, and measure either soluble reactive phosphorus (SRP) or total phosphorus (TP) instead of the more relevant bioavailable P (BAP;  the fraction of TP that aqueous organisms can use).  The major goal of this project was to develop an assay that uses the familiar organism S. cerevisiae (baker's yeast) to measure BAP in surface water, and to do so in a manner that is environmentally friendly (i.e., produces no hazardous waste), requires minimal training, and is adaptable to both laboratory and community (e.g., school) environments.

With NSF funding support, our interdisciplinary team, consisting of scientists trained in fields from cell biology to biogeochemistry, developed two versions of a yeast-based assay for bioavailable P: one which can process many samples in parallel and utilizes common laboratory equipment (microtiter plates and a plate-spectrophotometer), and one that is lower in throughput but more compatible with community settings (it utilizes commonly available 50-mL tubes and a standard spectrophotometer) [1].  We showed that both versions of the assay are capable of measuring P in ranges relevant to eutrophication (4?M to > 80?M P), and that for simple P sources (e.g., potassium phosphate), the resulting measurements are consistent with those obtained from standard SRP assays [1]. In this work, we provided detailed protocols so that others may effectively use these new assays.  In addition, we also showed that the assay is effective in field settings, using agricultural surface water samples, and that the assay generally produces values falling between SRP and TP [1, 2]. Finally, by using the yeast assay in a field setting under a range of hydrologic conditions,(e.g., dry periods,  storm events, or after physical disturbance) we were able to provide evidence that the fraction of TP that BAP comprises can vary [2].  We hope that our assays will become a standard part of P-measurement efforts in both laboratory and community-based testing programs.

Another goal of our work was to utilize the same principles applied in the assays described above, which test pre-acquired water samples, to develop a deployable yeast-based device that can provide P measurements in field settings on a continuous basis. Such a device could potentially be placed directly in agricultural runoff streams to pinpoint times and places where excess P enters waterways. The development of this in situ device is an ongoing effort, and thus this goal remains for future work.  We have used the continuous culture systems developed through this work to develop an improved assay for the presence of mutagens in water, one that is 10x more sensitive than the well-established Ames test [3].

This project also had a variety of broader impacts. For two years, we worked with a local public high school to integrate the community-based assay into a chemistry classroom, introducing students to the challenges associated with freshwater eutrophication, giving them hands-on experience in a real-life research problem [4].  Grant-supported personnel also coached the "Ecology" competition for another local high school's Science Olympiad team.  In addition, this project contributed to the production of two PhD theses, one master's degree, and a host of hands-on summer undergraduate and high school research experiences.

Overall, this NSF supported project led to the generation and validation of two sets of novel assays for the detection of environmental contaminants (phosphorus and mutagens), and provided hands-on, interdisciplinary research training for a range of high school, undergraduate, and graduate students. We hope that this project will have long-term impact through the training that it provided and through future use of our assays for environmental protection.

[1]    Shepherd, H. A. M., Trentman, M. T., Tank, J. L., Praner, J., Cervantes, A., Chaudhary, P.,Goodson, H. V. (2021). Development of a yeast-based assay for bioavailable phosphorus. ACS Environmental Science and Technology-Water, in press.

[2]    Trentman, M. T., Tank, J. L., Shepherd, H. A. M., Marrs, A. J., Welsh, J. R., & Goodson, H. V. (2021). Characterizing bioavailable phosphorus concentrations in an agricultural stream during hydrologic and streambed disturbances. Biogeochemistry, 154: 509-524. doi: 10.1007/s10533-021-00803-w.

[3]    Ong, J. Y., Pence, J. T., Molik, D. C., Shepherd, H. A. M., & Goodson, H. V. (2021). Yeast grown in continuous culture systems can detect mutagens with improved sensitivity relative to the Ames test. PLoS One, 16(3), e0235303.  https://doi.org/10.1371/journal.pone.0235303

[4]    Outdoor Elements (PBS TV show), April, 2017. Retrieved 2021-07-28 from https://www.wnit.org/outdoorelements/e/april-2nd-2017.html
